ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

WORKERS' PARTY DEMOCRACY DAY DINNER
(Refusal of licence)


    1. Mr Low Thia Khiang asked the Minister for Home Affairs if he will explain why a licence under the Public Entertainments Act was refused for the Workers' Party Democracy Day Dinner on 14th November 1992.

     The Minister for Home Affairs (Prof. S. Jayakumar): Mr Speaker, Sir, Police rejected the application because they considered the proposed venue, being a narrow strip of land between a major road and an HDB apartment block, was unsuitable for such a gathering organised by a political party. It was also too small to accommodate the 1,300 to 1,500 persons expected to attend it, and the available car parking facilities were insufficient.

    Subsequently, on 9th November 1992, the applicants proposed an alternative site which was approved.

     Mr Low Thia Khiang (Hougang): Sir, is the Minister aware that the site has been approved by MND as a wayang site?

     Prof. Jayakumar: Sir, a site for wayang is very different from a site for a political meeting organised by a political party. I

Column: 479

think the difference must be very obvious to all and the potential for breaches of the peace, law and disorder are considerably different.

     Mr Low Thia Khiang: Just now, the Minister mentioned about the suitability of the site and he said that it was a narrow strip of land. A wayang will also encourage crowd forming.

     Prof. Jayakumar: Sir, these are professional decisions which the Police must make, taking into account various factors. A wayang may attract a certain kind of crowd but a meeting organised by a political party, whether the PAP or opposition parties, has different connotations. The Police's concern is not to stop such meetings organised by political parties. Where political parties want to organise a gathering with speeches it, in fact, becomes a political meeting. Police's concern is that if it is held outdoors, close to HDB residential areas, then there is potential for mischief and disorder because it is difficult to distinguish those who are genuine supporters and invited guests and those who are not and might be heckling and causing trouble. In fact, there have been instances where objects have been thrown down from HDB flats. So these are some considerations which the Police take into account. It is not good enough to say that that site was used for a wayang and therefore it must automatically be approved for political parties. There are various law and order considerations which the Police have to take into account.

     Mr Low Thia Khiang: Sir, the Minister mentioned about public disorder and mischief. Would the Minister explain or clarify whether the Workers' Party Democracy Day Dinners in the past 10 years have caused any public disorder or mischief?

     Prof. Jayakumar: I am not sure whether the Police have had any problems in past Democracy Day dinners. But their concern is the potential for trouble and that is the prime consideration for approving such sites.

     Mr Low Thia Khiang: Does the Minister agree that the potential is something which is perceived?

Column: 480



     Prof. Jayakumar: It is not only perceived, but there have actually been cases, both during election periods and outside election periods, where there have been breaches of the peace, disorder, unruly behaviour and, therefore, there are very good reasons for the cautious approach taken by the Police.

     Mr Low Thia Khiang: Sir, have Democracy Day dinners of the Workers' Party in the past caused any public disorder? Please do not compare it with election rallies.

     Prof. Jayakumar: Sir, I think we can go on and on. I have answered the question which he had already asked.

     Mr Low Thia Khiang: The Minister mentioned just now that car parking facilities were one of the considerations. Does the Minister know the number of car park lots in the vicinity of the site?

     Prof. Jayakumar: If Ministers have to carry all these bits of information, then they will not be able to do any work.

     Mr Low Thia Khiang: For the information of the Minister, there are 344 motor car parking lots in the vicinity and 106 motor-cycle parking lots. Why did PELU (Public Entertainments Licensing Unit) consider car parking facilities as a criterion for refusing to grant the licence?

     Prof. Jayakumar: Sir, I fail to understand the purport of the question. I have just mentioned some of the considerations that the Police have to take into account and one of the considerations is, of course, the congestion that can be created by people coming into the particular area, the displacement of car parks for residents in the area and the congestion that will be created after the dinner or the political meeting.

     Mr Low Thia Khiang: Is the Minister saying that if the permit were given for this instance and there were speeches, it may pose a security threat to Singapore?

     Prof. Jayakumar: Mr Speaker, Sir, I never said that. I thought I made it very clear. Political parties can have functions anywhere and any time. But if they are going to have functions where there are

Column: 481

going to be speeches and these functions are organised by political parties, Police's preference and requirement is that they be held indoors or within stadiums or athletic centres. Police will not allow such political meetings to be held outdoors and close to residential estates.

     Mr Low Thia Khiang: Does the Minister agree that the ground which the Minister has mentioned in refusing the permit is based on unreal imagination and is a manifestation of the paranoia of this Government?

     Prof. Jayakumar: Sir, the Member can choose to describe it in whatever way he likes. But I can assure him that the Police will not change their attitude because it is that strict insistence on law and order that has prevented us from rendering ourselves into situations which other countries have where mayhem, chaos, riots, fisticuffs and so on take place on a regular basis.

     Mr Low Thia Khiang: Supplementary question, Sir?

     Mr Speaker: Mr Low, it appears to me you are asking more or less the same question. Unless you have something new, we will have to move on because we have a lot of questions today.

     Mr Low Thia Khiang: Last question, Sir.

     Mr Speaker: All right, last question.

     Mr Low Thia Khiang: Does the Minister agree that the refusal by PELU to grant the permit is designed to deny the Workers' Party leaders from making public speeches and to make it difficult for the Party to organise the dinner?

     Prof. Jayakumar: Of course, I do not agree because the Workers' Party, as I said, is free to organise rallies and meetings within stadiums or athletic centres. They can have a very big crowd. They can open it to the press. So how is that a denial of freedom of the press or freedom of information. The same requirement and the same considerations which I mentioned will also be applicable if an application was made by the PAP.

10-YEAR COMPULSORY EDUCATION SCHEME
(Timing and mode of operation)


    2. Dr Kanwaljit Soin asked the Minister for Education if he will give details of the timing and mode of operation of the 10-year scheme of compulsory education for every child in Singapore.

     The Minister for Education (Mr Lee Yock Suan): Mr Speaker, Sir, starting from 1991, the Ministry of Education has introduced refinements to the education system to provide every child with at least 10 years of general education - six years of primary education and at least four years of secondary education. However, education is not compulsory in Singapore.

    Primary education comprises two stages - a 4-year Foundation stage and a 2-year Orientation stage. The Foundation stage aims at providing pupils with a good foundation in English, the mother tongue and Mathematics, while the Orientation stage offers a differentiated curriculum to match the different learning needs of pupils. At the end of Primary 6, all pupils will sit for a modified Primary School Leaving Examination, which will place them in an appropriate secondary course.

    In addition to the present Special, Express and Normal (Academic) courses in secondary schools, a new course - the Normal (Technical) course - will be introduced in 1994. This course will be technical-oriented and will prepare pupils for further technical-vocational education and training at the Institute of Technical Education. These pupils will take the GCE N-level examination at the end of four years and those who are able will do an additional year and take the O-level examination.

    At the end of 10 years of general education, pupils may pursue further education and training at junior colleges, polytechnics and the Institute of Technical Education, depending on their interests and abilities.

     Dr Kanwaljit Soin (Nominated Member): Why is the Minister not willing to make 10 years of education compulsory for every child?

Column: 483



     Mr Lee Yock Suan: Mr Speaker, Sir, whether a pupil benefits from being in school and whether he learns and progresses depends on his interest and motivation. We feel that if we just force the pupils to remain in school, it will not really solve the problem. There are cases, for example, where pupils, because of family problems, have to leave school. The principal and teachers will counsel these pupils and their parents and persuade them to stay on. Our drop-out rate from school is very low compared to other countries. On balance, we feel there is no need for us to introduce compulsory education.

     Dr Kanwaljit Soin: Would the Minister agree with the Advisory Council for Youths' figure that 6.8% of the young have less than PSLE education? That is one supplementary question. Can I go on to the second supplementary question, Sir?

     Mr Speaker: Yes.

     Dr Kanwaljit Soin: Does the Minister not agree with the wish expressed in the Next Lap that every Singaporean should have at least 10 years of education? The third supplementary question is: With the new organisation of the ITE, you can only get in if you have at least 10 years of basic education. So the school drop-outs would not have an opportunity to join this institution.

     Mr Lee Yock Suan: Mr Speaker, Sir, I do not have the figure with me but I think the figure of 6-7% of pupils not completing primary education is probably within the ballpark. It goes to show that the drop-out rate is very low, especially in the primary school stage. The ones who leave tend to be the ones who are in the Extended stream. They are 13-14 years old and the problem is that usually they will go, for example, for vacation jobs. Once they have tasted the working experience and they have money, they tend not to come back. There is a tendency to try to drop out. It is important that the schools persuade and counsel them.

    The drop-out rates are higher in the secondary level. That is the stage when

Column: 484

the children are older. Our system tries to keep them in school for 10 years. So I fully agree with her that we should, as far as possible, keep the children in school for at least 10 years. But it is no point forcing them to stay. It is only through persuasion, teaching and motivating them that we can achieve the result.

    As for the ITE, the intention is that eventually they will accept pupils who have completed secondary education. But this is still a plan and, if necessary, we may modify it to take in some of the other pupils or we may, for example, help to place them in factories through apprenticeship programmes. The whole point is to prepare our young people with education for proper employment eventually. While I agree fully with her on this point, it is a matter of approach. We feel that compulsion is not the way to do it.

     Dr Kanwaljit Soin: Sir, would the Minister then agree that there is a relationship between early school drop-outs and youths at risk? The Minister has not convinced me that there is no need for compulsory education.

     Mr Lee Yock Suan: This problem of school drop-outs is a very big social problem in many countries. Fortunately for us, it is contained to very small proportions. For example, at each level, the drop-out rate is less than 1%. And if we take a cohort going through the whole 10 years of schooling, it comes up to about 6-7%, as she has mentioned.

    It is a total social problem. The Ministry on its part will do its best. We counsel the parents, we counsel the students, we try and give them more opportunities to come back to school if they want to. But in the end, we have to work with other groups, eg, SINDA, MENDAKI and CDAC. The intention is that we will henceforth refer some of these cases to these other organisations to look more closely into their social background, whether they have financial difficulties, whether they have learning difficulties and try to keep them in school and motivate them to learn, but not through compulsion.

Column: 485



     Mr Low Thia Khiang: Sir, does the Ministry of Education have records to monitor children who have reached school-going age but whose parents have not registered them for school?

    The Minister mentioned about counselling for parents whose children have left school. I would like to know from the Minister what sort of counselling the Ministry is providing and in what way.

     Mr Lee Yock Suan: Sir, as for the first question, I believe we do have the records, but I have to confirm this because I am speaking from memory.

    As for the second question, counselling is done by the teachers who know the pupils. As soon as they find that the pupils have lost interest and are showing signs of wanting to leave school, the teachers counsel them, the principals counsel them and the Ministry also gets involved with the counselling process. It is a matter of talking to them and trying to understand their problems and explaining to them why they should stay in school. So it depends on the case involved.

     Dr Kanwaljit Soin: Sir, does the Minister not agree that there is a need to have a structured mechanism to follow up on these drop-outs? What the Minister has mentioned is what happens at the initial stage, but there is no structured mechanism to follow up on what these drop-outs do and then to fit them into maybe apprentice systems or some other system. From the figure of the National Council of Social Service, is the Minister aware that there were 57,000 disadvantaged youths in 1990, most of whom dropped out from school?

     Mr Lee Yock Suan: Mr Speaker, Sir, I agree with her that we should have a proper mechanism to counsel and, if possible, to follow up. But it is a total problem involving not only ourselves. It has to involve, for example, community organisations. It has to involve the families especially. In a practical sense, it is a big problem because the numbers are big. The schools are already loaded with their problems of providing general education. We do our best to persuade them and to keep track of them. But it has

Column: 486

got to be a total approach involving not only ourselves but other groups. And to some extent, I think Members are straying away from the main line of the Question. If Members have interest in this topic, we can discuss it in the Budget debate.

     Mr Speaker: I want to remind Members that supplementary questions should be related to the original Question and they should not stray too far away from the subject under discussion. Dr Toh.

     Dr Toh Keng Kiat (Nominated Member): Sir, as some students have dropped out because they cannot fit into the usual school system because of a structured syllabus, will the Ministry consider a special programme like tutelage to bring these children back to school?

     Mr Lee Yock Suan: The schools are already providing remedial lessons. For pupils who have difficulties in various subjects, the teachers will get them to stay back after school and provide additional lessons. I think a lot of pupils on their own have tuition. There could be other cases, eg, where the pupils need special help and they could be referred to special schools, schools for the disabled and so on. There are various special schemes available.

SMOKING IN SINGAPORE ARMED FORCES


    3. Dr Tan Cheng Bock asked the Minister for Defence (a) whether his Ministry has data on the extent of smoking in the Singapore Armed Forces, in particular among national servicemen; (b) whether national servicemen who smoke picked up the habit during National Service; (c) whether his Ministry has or will consider measures to help SAF servicemen cut down on smoking; and (d) whether, in support of the National Anti-Smoking Programme, the SAF will consider prohibiting its servicemen in uniform from smoking in public.

     The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Defence (Mr Matthias Yao Chih) (for the Minister for Defence): Sir, I am answering on behalf of the Minister.

    MINDEF pays close attention to the health and fitness of SAF servicemen.

Column: 487

Smoking is a health hazard that can lead to serious diseases and early death. It also undermines the physical fitness and performance of our soldiers. As part of its overall anti-smoking effort, MINDEF has been conducting annual smoking surveys among SAF servicemen since 1986. The survey results enable MINDEF to monitor the trend and take corrective actions. The surveys show that fewer servicemen are smoking than before. In 1986, 41% of all active servicemen smoked. This was reduced to 23% by 1991. The same year's survey showed that 24% of national servicemen smoked. Unfortunately, in line with an increase in smokers nationwide, these figures have increased to 27% and 29% respectively in 1992. The overwhelming majority, ie, 93% of national servicemen who smoke acquired the habit before entering service. 42% of them started smoking before they were 15 years old while 51% started smoking between 15 years old and the time of their enlistment.

    In 1986, MINDEF started a three-pronged smoking control programme to discourage smoking in the SAF and to protect non-smokers from the hazards of side stream smoke. The smoking control programme serves, firstly, to educate SAF personnel on the harmful effects of smoking; second, to help smokers quit the habit and, third, to deter smoking. The SAF runs inhouse smoking cessation clinics to help smokers to quit the habit. These measures have resulted in reducing the prevalence of smoking in the SAF.

    MINDEF is currently studying additional ways to discourage smoking among its servicemen and to help those who smoke to quit. Prohibiting servicemen in uniform from smoking in public is one of the measures being considered.

MEDISAVE
(Transfer of funds from CPF ordinary account)


    The following Question stood in the name of Mrs Yu-Foo Yee Shoon -

    5. To ask the Minister for Health whether a person whose Medisave account is exhausted can have funds from his/her ordinary account transferred to the Medisave account to pay for medical expenses.

     Dr Tan Cheng Bock: Question No. 5, Sir.

     The Minister for Health (Mr Yeo Cheow Tong): Sir, currently, Medisave has a contribution limit of $15,000. Contributions in excess of $15,000 are automatically transferred to the Ordinary Account to avoid excessive accumulation of Medisave. A member who has had excess contributions transferred to the Ordinary Account can apply to have the amount transferred back to his Medisave Account, if he has exhausted his Medisave.

    However, if there had not been any such previous transfer, the member will not be allowed to transfer any savings from the Ordinary Account to his Medisave Account. But the member may be allowed to pay for his medical expenses with future Medisave contributions provided he receives treatment in a Class C or B2 ward of a Government or restructured hospital.

GOVERNMENT-OWNED COMPANIES
(Profits and losses)


    7. Encik Harun bin A. Ghani asked the Minister for Finance, since 1988, (i) what is the number of government-owned companies which have been making profits, (ii) whether that number exceeds the number of companies which have incurred losses and (iii) what is the excess of profits over losses of these companies.

     Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau: Mr Speaker, Sir, as Questions 6 and 7 are related, may I take them together?

     Mr Speaker: Yes.

     Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau: Sir, Government companies are held under three group companies, namely, Temasek Holdings, MND Holdings and Singapore Technologies Holdings.

    At the group level, Temasek Holdings and MND Holdings have been profitable in every year from 1988 to 1991. In the case of Singapore Technologies Holdings, it was profitable in 1988, 1989 and 1990 but suffered a loss of $91.1 million in 1991. The loss arose as a result of losses incurred by a subsidiary company, Singapore Technologies Ventures, and reasons for the loss were given in this House in response to a question from Mr Low last year.

    1992 results for the three holding companies are not yet available but all the three are expected to be profitable.

    On Question No. 7, the number of Government-owned companies including the three holding companies, namely, Temasek Holdings, Singapore Technologies Holdings and MND Holdings and their first tier companies which were profitable since 1988 are as follows: 

         1988      -   34 companies

         1989      -   33 companies

         1990      -   36 companies

         1991      -   34 companies


    These companies which lost money during those years were 6 in 1988, 7 in 1989, 7 in 1990 and 10 in 1991.

Column: 490



    The number of profitable companies therefore exceeded the number of companies which incurred losses in each of the years from 1988 to 1990.

    The excess profits over losses of these companies are as follows: 

            1988      -   $1,215 million
